message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including mucositis and skin lesions, are consistent with Steven-Johnson Syndrome. Erythema multiforme and Herpes Simplex virus may cause similar skin lesions but would not involve mucositis. Herpes zoster would present with unilateral vesicular eruptions along a dermatome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of coalescing erythematous macules, bullae, desquamation, and mucositis along with the presence of ulcers and erythema in the oropharynx suggests Steven-Johnson syndrome as the most likely diagnosis. Erythema multiforme usually presents with target lesions, Herpes simplex virus and Herpes zoster typically present with grouped vesicles.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The coalescing erythematous macules, bullae, desquamation, and mucositis suggest the diagnosis of Steven-Johnson syndrome, which is characterized by a widespread eruption of erythematous macules, patches, and plaques. Erythema multiforme would present with target lesions, while herpes simplex virus and herpes zoster would present with vesicular eruptions. The ulcers and erythema in the oropharynx support the diagnosis of Steven-Johnson syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Steven-Johnson Syndrome, which is associated with significant mucosal involvement and is often triggered by medication use. Erythema multiforme would typically present with targetoid lesions, while Herpes simplex virus and Herpes zoster would have vesicles or pustules.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The rash, which started abruptly with mucositis, and involvement of the upper half of the back along with ulcers in the oropharynx are suggestive of Steven-Johnson syndrome. Herpes simplex virus and Herpes zoster would present with vesicles instead of bullae, and erythema multiforme typically presents with symmetric target lesions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Steven-Johnson syndrome, which presents with coalescing erythematous macules, bullae, desquamation, and mucositis. Herpes simplex virus and Herpes zoster can present with similar symptoms, but they usually appear as vesicles instead of bullae. Erythema multiforme usually presents with target lesions, not bullae. The ulcers and erythema in the oropharynx are also consistent with Steven-Johnson syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms that the patient presents, including the location of the rash, desquamation, mucositis, and oropharyngeal ulcers, are most consistent with Steven-Johnson syndrome. The other options, such as herpes simplex virus and herpes zoster, typically present with vesicular lesions, which are not seen in this case. Erythema multiforme may present with similar symptoms, but it is usually milder and self-limiting, and the location of the rash is usually more widespread.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of coalescing erythematous macules, bullae, desquamation, and mucositis along with oropharynx ulcers and erythema strongly suggest Steven-Johnson syndrome. Erythema multiforme typically spares the mucous membranes and has a more benign course. Herpes simplex and herpes zoster typically present with characteristic vesicular lesions, which are absent in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described in the question are consistent with Steven-Johnson syndrome, which is a serious reaction to medication or infection. Herpes simplex virus and herpes zoster would present with different symptoms such as grouped vesicular eruptions. Erythema multiforme may present with similar symptoms but without mucositis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of rash, mucositis, and ulcers suggest a severe drug reaction, and Steven-Johnson syndrome is the most likely diagnosis. The coalescing erythematous macules and bullae are more severe than those of erythema multiforme, and herpes simplex virus or herpes zoster typically present with a rash in a dermatomal distribution, which is not the case here.
